bibl.title: Ng Kwack Kang v. King County. Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p:
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the application of NG KWACK KANG, for a Writ of habeas corpus.
No. 3157 Patition of NG KWACK KANG, by and through ADAM BEELER of the law firm of BEELER and SULLIVAN, his attorney.
Comes now ADAM BEELER, of the firm of BEELER and SULLIVAN, Attorneys, as attorney for and in behalf of NG KWACK KANG, a son of NG KUM, an American citizen of the City of Boston. State of Massachusetts, and respectfully makes his application for a Writ of habeas corpus, and alleges as follows:
I. That the said NG KWACK KANG, is imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by the Unites States Commissioner of Immigration, HENRY M. WHITE, or by some person or persons acting through, by, or under him, and that said NG KWACK KANG is imprisoned at the Detention House at the Immigration Station in the City of Seattle, King County, State of Washington, and within the jurisdiction of the above entitled court, under the charge that the said NG KWACK KANG is an alien, a subject to the President of the Chinese Republic, and has no legal right to be admitted into the United States, and that he should be deported according to law; and your petitioner further informs this Honorable Court that said imprisonment, restraint, and Order of Deportation is Illegal, arising from the following facts, to-writ: That the said NG KWACK KANG arrived at the Port of Seattle on a voyge from China, on or about June 26th, 1915, on the S.S. TITAN, and said NG KWACK KANG was denied admittance into the United States on the ground that he was not legally entitled to be admitted therein; that said NG KWACK KANG was given a hearing by the Immigration officials on or about the 30th day of June, 1915; that further evidence was taken in said case by the Department of Labor, through

the Immigration officils; and that on the 16th day of August, 1915, an Order was issued by the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, finding that said NG KWACK KANG was not entitled to enter or remain in the United States, and that he should be deported; that an appeal was taken by said NG KWACK KANG, through his attorney in Boston, Massachusetts, to the Secretary, then on October 21st, 1915, said Order of Deportation was affirmed by the Assistant Secretary, and said NG KWACK KANG was ordered deported.
Your petitioner is informed and believes, and so states the fact to be, that said Commisioner of Immigration, HENRY M. WHITE of Seattle, Washington, in charge of the District of Washington, or his agent or agents, acting by, under, or through him, for the United States Government, is about to deport and return the said NG KWACK KANG to China, in violation of treaty relations between the United States and China, and in violation of the laws and statutes of the United States in relation to the Chinese Exclusion Act, and in violation of the laws relative to the acts and powers of the Secretary of Labor and the Assistant Secretary of Labor, in that said NG KWACK KANG is being deprived of his liberty without due process of law and without being given a fair hearing by said Commissioner of Immigration, HENRY M. WHITE, or his agents or officials, acting by, under or through him or for the United States Government.
Your petitioner further alleges that the right of appeal from the finding of the Commisssioner of Immigration, HENRY M. WHITE, or his agents or officials, acting by, under or through him, or for the United States Government in and for the District of Washington, by the statutes in such cases made and provided for in relation to the Chinese Exclusion Laws, has been violated and that his full rights have not been accorded to your petitioner, NG KWACK KANG in this: that W.B. WILSON is the Secretary of Labor, and LOUIS POST

is his only Assistant Secretary of Labor; that the said appeal of said NG KWACK KANG to the Secretary of Labor, from the decision denying the right to enter and remain int he United States, came up for hearing and consideration, and under the law should have been heard by the said Secretary of Labor, unless the said Secretary being absent, then said Assistant Secretary should Act, but that the said Order affirming the finding of the said Commissioner of Immigration of Seattle, is made by and in the name of the Assistant Secretary, without designation any name or authority so vested in Assistant Secretary, or that the said Secretary was absent and not able to perform his duty, and that the said Secretary of Labor neglected or refused to hear or consider said appeal, and hence the said NG KWACK KANG has been denied his right of appeal, according to law.
Your petitioner on information and belief, further states that the said NG KWACK KANG has not had a fair and impartial trial before the said NG KWACK KANG has not had a fair and impartial trial before the said Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, King County, Washington; that there is no evidence in the records to sustain the Exclusion and Deportation Order that said decision is arbitrary and not supported by evidence, and that said NG KWACK KANG, after the Department had given him a hearing before the Immigration Official at Seattle, Washington, was not advised of his right to have witnesses appear for and in his behalf; that said NG KWACK KANG was denied the right to face the witnesses whose testimony was taken by the United States Government, or the right of cross-examination thereof, and that evidence was taken without NG KWACK KANG being then and there facing said witnesses who gave evidnce for and in behalf of the United States Government.
Your petitioner further states that said NG KWACK KANG was denied a fair hearing, in that private confidentual letters passed between the Immigration Officials and the officials of the

Department of Labor at Washington, and that NG KWACK KANG was not apprised of said communications, or given the right to cross-examine the parties who wrote said letters, and tha said parties who wrote said letters were not under oath, and said letters were prejudicial, were not legal evidence, and the writing and consideration of same in connection with NG KWACK KANG's case denied him a fair and impartial hearing.
Your petition further alleges that NG KWACK KANG is a minor son of an American Citizen, NG KUM, his father having been discharged from custody by the United States District Judge Cox of the Northern District of New York, on April 11th, 1901, and to deny NG KWACK KANG, of his right to enter and remain in the United States, is depriving him of his liberty without due process of law, and is in violation of the Constitution of the Unites States.
Wherefore, your petitioner prays that his court find that said NG KWACK KANG has not been accorded the rights and privileges as allowed by law, and that he has not been given a fair and impartial trial, and that he is a son of an American citizen, and that he be discharged and allowed to join his father, who is an American citizen in Boston, Massachusetts.
DATED this 10th day of November 1915.
NG KWACK KANG, petitioner BY and THROUGH Adam Beeler
Attorney for petitioner.
STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING}SS
ADAM BEELER, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is one of the attorneys for the said NG KWACK KANG: that he has read the foregoing Patition, knows the contents thereof, and that the same is true, of his knowledge, he alleges upon information and belief to be true Adam Beeler Subscribed and sworn to before me this 10th day of November 1915. W.S. Law Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.

The President of the United States of America, to United States Commissioner of Immigration, HENRY M. WHITE:
We command you that you have the body of NG KWACK KANG, by you imprisoned and detained under Order of Deportation, as it is said, together with the time and cause of such imprisonment and detention and order of deportation by whatsoever name the said NG KWACK KANG, shall be named or charged. before Honorable JEREMIAH NETERER. Judge of the Unites States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, at the Federal Building, in Seattle, State of Washington, on the 15th day of November, 1915, at Two P.M
